abstract: News Analysis; Supreme Court makes unusual move in agreeing to hear four same-sex marriage cases by rephrasing questions in petitions; some see housekeeping in court's language, but others sense subtle shift of emphasis, away from rights of people to get married and toward due process and equal protection obligations that 14th Amendment imposes on states.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court does not ordinarily tinker with the wording of questions in petitions, but it did so in agreeing to rule on same-sex marriage.
snippet: The Supreme Court does not ordinarily tinker with the wording of questions in petitions, but it did so in agreeing to rule on same-sex marriage.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

headline.main: Taking Up Gay Marriage, but on Its Own Terms
headline.print_headline: Taking Up Gay Marriage, but on Their Own Terms
